The letter asked me to state whether I had or had not witnessed anything untoward during the operations.I had not. &ldquoWhat I witnessed was the exemplary way in which all duties were carried out by our forces under very trying conditions.The letter stressed that any involvement would be &ldquoentirely confidential and voluntary (Image: NO CREDIT )Mr Bedwell, who is now 83 and a bell ringer at his local church in Cornwall, added: &ldquoAnyone claiming compensation for anything that happened 62 years ago should have done it by now.&nbsp&ldquoIt seems to me that someone is pulling their strings and this Government is going along with it. It beggars belief.&ldquoSeeing recent reports of doubtful payments of huge sums of money being paid after the Iraq and Afghanistan campaigns and the disgraceful hounding of old soldiers who only did their duty in Ulster, I am of the opinion that the Government must stop this nonsense now and institute a statute of limitations law immediately.This is the latest legal challenge faced by the British military.Troops faced 3,400 allegations of wrongdoing in Iraq &ndash the vast majority levelled by a now disgraced law firm.                British Special Forces send 20 troops into Red Sea port                Last Hurrah for the Great War&rsquos forgotten heroesIn Cyprus in many cases the troops were National Servicemen (Image: BERT HARDYPICTURE POST )The inquiries cost the taxpayer &pound34million and military personnel years of anguish but failed to secure a single prosecution.Meanwhile, four British soldiers are facing trial over incidents in Northern Ireland dating back as far as 1972 &ndash despite having been cleared of wrongdoing at the time.Another 278 cases involving Northern Ireland veterans are thought to be under investigation.And the Government has faced compensation claims over its handling of the Mau Mau uprising in Kenya from 1952 to 1963.Stereoscopic slides documenting life on the Western front during WW1 have now come to light 100 years on.                    H.Aldridge&ampSonsBNPS1 of 17A group of British Tommies looking down at the impression left in the grass made by the unfortunate airmenThe claims relating to the Cyprus Emergency were given the go-ahead earlier this year when the High Court cleared the way for 34 elderly Greek Cypriots to seek damages from Britain over allegations of torture and human rights abuses.The allegations centre on the Greek Cypriot insurgency which led to independence in 1960.The Government denies the claims.The chairman of the all-party Commons Defence Committee, Julian Lewis, said: &ldquoWhat is totally outrageous is for the Government to go on fishing expeditions of this sort so long after the event.British Marine guards in Cyrus, 1956  (Image: BERT HARD PICTURE POST  )&ldquoFor anything like this to be pursued there needs to be overwhelming evidence of wrongdoing in the past and a reasonable explanation of why the matter is only now being pursued.The failure to grasp the problem in relation to Northern Ireland is fuelling the concerns of veterans including those who fought and won the Falklands campaign that they will be next to be targeted.&ldquoAny country that cannot protect its service personnel from this phenomenon of so-called &lsquolawfare&rsquo does not deserve to have servicemen and women defending it in uniform.If you take this to its logical conclusion you could see Second World War RAF personnel hounded through the courts by people who lost relatives to bombing of German cities.The majority of troops were National Servicemen who had no wish to be thrust into the front line (Image: NO CREDIT)Cyprus veteran Les Smith, who is tracing relatives of personnel killed in Cyprus so they can claim the Elizabeth Medal, said: &ldquoWe lost 371 personnel plus 21 British policemen in Cyprus but this gets brushed under the carpet. Now this has reared its ugly head. It is awful.Les, 80, from Lancashire, who served as a driver in Cyprus between 1957 and 1959, added: &ldquoMost of the 22,000 who served there were National Servicemen and very few of us wanted to be there.&ldquoThey were a ruthless enemy and like any terrorist you did not know who they were. Wires were put across roads so if you had a jeep they would chop your head off.&ldquoI do not think it is reasonable to pursue people who were out there doing their duty and who are now at least in their late 70s.                Leo Docherty urges support for petition to protect veteransI think that to a man the veterans will be disgusted that this kind of thing is happening now.It is about lawyers trying to jump on the bandwagon and make money.Air Chief Marshal Sir Michael Graydon, who served in Cyprus in the 1960s and was a patron of a campaign to build a memorial to the fallen on the island, said: &ldquoThe evidence is on the side of those who think there are people out there looking for an opportunity to make a bit of money.In Cyprus in many cases the troops were National Servicemen &ndash and then 60 years on they find themselves involved in litigation.                Forces chief: My deep unease over Ulster veterans hauled into court                It&rsquos about time we had a Defence Secretary stand up for our menThere&rsquos got to be a big question mark about the proposition that you can remember what happened 60 years ago.A Government spokesman said: &ldquoThe claim we are currently defending is for compensation, not a criminal investigation.No veterans are required to take part in the Government&rsquos defence and any discussions they voluntarily take part in will be strictly confidential.&ldquoWe recognise the concerns people have raised over historic allegations, and that&rsquos why the Defence Secretary recently created a dedicated team to consider this important issue and advise on the way forward.Incredible images shows London during the Blitz of 1940-1941 and present day, to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the end of the Blitz in London on May 11, 2016                    Getty1 of 14Incredible images shows London during the Blitz of 1940-1941 and present dayBRUTAL conflict on an island with bloody pastTHE Cyprus Emergency was a brutal insurgency in the Mediterranean Crown Colony which reached its peak as Britain was retreating from Empire.It pitted a Greek Cypriot rebel force &ndash EOKA or the National Organisation of Cypriot Fighters &ndash against both British troops and the Turkish minority from 1955 to 1959.And it was marked by terrorist tactics that would become familiar to British troops in Northern Ireland &ndash notably home-made bombs and assassinations carried out in a bid to make Britain hand the island over to Greece.Other tactics included deploying wires across roads to decapitate troops racing past in open-topped vehicles.In about five years Britain lost 371 personnel and 21 policemen, some of them to accidents, but many to terrorism.The majority of troops were National Servicemen who had no wish to be thrust into the front line. They served alongside professional troops including Paratroopers, Guardsmen and Royal Marines.Much of the cat and mouse pursuit of terrorists centred on the Troodos Mountains which were perfect for guerrilla warfare.But the main street of Nicosia became known as &ldquoMurder Mile because of assassinations.EOKA were led by George Grivas, a Cypriot-born retired Right-wing Greek officer, and inspired by Archbishop Makarios, the head of the Greek Orthodox Church on the island, who wanted it handed over to Athens and Cyprus was granted independence in 1960.But in 1974 the island became ided when Turkey invaded in response to a new attempt to unite it with Greece. Keith Lloyd, who served with the Welsh Guards and lives in Turkish-controlled Northern Cyprus, said: &ldquoEOKA&rsquos favourite method of murder was to shoot British personnel in the back while they were shopping.But the counter insurgency campaign led to suspects being rounded up and interrogated.And the British Government is now fighting compensation claims in the courts over allegations that Greek Cypriot prisoners were tortured during interrogation.

title: Brexit news Theresa May Chequers leave EU treaties tory party Barnier James Cleverly
story: Mr Cleverly argued we could re-work entrenched EU treaties (Image:  )Mr Cleverly argued if we obtained a trade deal Brussels didn&rsquot agree with, we could re-work entrenched treaties to suit our needs in future.The Tory Party&rsquos Deputy Chairman stated he wouldn&rsquot rule out trade deals at variance with the EU&rsquos common rulebook after &ldquoBrexit day on March 29, 2019.Speaking to The Daily &rsquos Chopper&rsquos Brexit Podcast, he said: &ldquoIf at some point we got a trade deal proposal which contradicts elements of the common rulebook then we can do that judgement.&ldquoYou can make and unmake treaties. Treaties can be unmade.Mr Cleverly appeared to imply getting out of the bloc itself was fundamental - while the undoing of treaties could be achieved later down the line.He said: &ldquoNo one is pretending the Chequers proposal is going to satisfy everybody.But he claimed Mrs May&rsquos Brexit blueprint did deliver on the referendum's promises to take back control of our money, borders and laws.He also vowed the UK would be able to cary out far-reaching, global trade deals once it had withdrawn from the EU.Government sources said there had been a &ldquoshift in language since Mrs May' Chequers plans  (Image: )He maintained if the opportunities outweighed the consequences of splitting from Brussels to achieve a deal elsewhere, the UK could do that.He said: &ldquoIt doesn't happen a lot, but it can be done.Mr Cleverly left it up to the Prime Minister to determine how best to steer the UK forward.He explained she could make her decisions on a case-by-case basis in future - as long as the UK was outside the EU.Mrs May, who is still trying to convince the public and EU leaders of her Chequers plans&rsquo proficiency, could be asked to sign even more concessions in Brussels ahead of the UK&rsquos imminent ceasing of free movement and trade.It was reported that the UK&rsquos future relationship with the EU would echo the bloc&rsquos relationship with Jersey and other Channel Islands - and allow the UK to keep a single market for goods.Government sources revealed on Thursday it was clear there had been a &ldquoshift in language from the EU following Theresa May&rsquos Chequers proposals.On Thrusday night, Tory Brexiteers insisted the Prime Minister hold her nerve and rule out any further compromise.

title: House of Fraser Mike Ashley Dragons Den Touker Suleyman sports direct retail Newsnight BBC
story: Mr Ashley bought House of Fraser in a &pound90million deal that raised questions about its future (Image:  )Mr Ashley, whose Sports Direct operations have been fraught with controversy, owns a erse retail portfolio, which s from discount stores to luxury, high-end fashion.The English billionaire&rsquos recent buyout of House of Fraser has thrown the fate of its 59 stores and 17,500 employees into doubt.Touker Suleyman, fashionretail giant and well known TV personality, spoke on yesterday&rsquos Newsnight programme to defend Mr Ashley.The retail magnate and Dragons&rsquo Den stalwart offered that Mr Ashley was an admirable figure, due to the gumption of his entrepreneurial spirit and business acumen.                Massacre on the high street: Now internet giants face tax demand                Customers fear chain will head downmarket&ldquoHe will need another 70million to make the plan work.Mr Suleyman revealed he did believe House of Fraser had a future.He said: &ldquoThe reason I believe that is because it is a very personalised group of department stores.He ulged he had been in the Birmingham House of Fraser branch about three weeks ago and had toured its 500,000 square feet of store.Mr Ashley is known for Sports Direct, which has drawn criticism for the way it treats its staff (Image:  )Two committees of MPs have questioned Mike Ashley about working conditions and pay at Sports Direct (Image: )He said: &ldquoI was speaking to the lady in charge and there are some great people on the ground - passionate about the store.&ldquoThe important thing is, if I had bought the business I would visit every store, see the people on the ground and see the value there.He added: &ldquoThe biggest assets are the people on the ground.The entrepreneur and investor, who has been on two series of Dragons&rsquo Den, admitted he didn&rsquot think it would be easy for Mr Ashley to instil a new culture in the department store chain.He said: &ldquoI don&rsquot think you are going to change the House of Fraser culture that quickly.&ldquoI don&rsquot think Mike Ashley is going to wave a magic wand and say, &lsquoRight, these are my conditions.&rsquo&ldquoI think they are set-in - within House of Fraser.

title: ben bishop detectorist elizabethan gold ring auction treasure 10000
story: Ben Bishop found a Elizabethan signet ring that is set to make up to &pound10,000 at auction (Image: HANSONS)Ben, 30, from Bridgwater, Somerset, said: &ldquoI wasn&rsquot expecting to find anything except a few coins, buckles or buttons.&ldquoI thought it was another Coke can ring-pull &ndash I&rsquove found tons of those over the years along with lots of rubbish.&ldquoBut I saw something shining and, when I broke off the mud, this beautiful ancient gold ring appeared before my eyes.&ldquoIt is something I will remember forever.&ldquoIt&rsquos the first gold I&rsquove ever found. I was so gobsmacked I just sat down on the ground staring at it for about 40 minutes.                Slab of gold nicknamed 'lightning bolt' expected to sell for 80K                 Guillotine and electric chair up for sale in grisly auctionThe ring was unearthed last August in a farmer&rsquos field near Glastonbury, Somerset, where Ben, a metal detectorist for seven years, had permission to dig. He registered the find as treasure trove but it was returned to him after examination. Throne Now the gold signet ring, featuring a double-headed eagle, will be sold at Hansons Auctioneers in Derbyshire on September 27 with an estimate of &pound7,500 to &pound10,000. Signet rings were used to mark a wax seal on documents identifying who was sending them. Ben, a factory technician, said: &ldquoI thought it may have been Eastern European but it turns out that the eagle symbol was used on lead tokens when Elizabeth I was on the throne.&ldquoThe ring was taken away for a couple of months to be examined and the British Museum did a report on it. No museums wanted to buy it so it was returned to me as the finder.The ring was unearthed last August in a farmer&rsquos field near Glastonbury (Image: HANSONS)&ldquoI had an agreement with the owner of the field that if I found anything of high value I would sell it and split the proceeds. &ldquoIt&rsquos a man&rsquos ring and fits my finger really well, but I have to part with it. &ldquoI have no idea who it originally belonged to but it would have been a person of wealth and importance. Glastonbury Abbey isn&rsquot far away. Gems expert Kate Bliss of TV&rsquos Bargain Hunt and Flog It! said of the find &ndash confirmed as Elizabethan and dated to between 1550 and 1650: &ldquoThis gold signet ring bowled me over. &ldquoDepicting a double headed eagle on a flat oval bezel with beaded border, the ring weighs in at an unusually heavy 17gm. Ben said: &ldquoI don&rsquot do this for the money &ndash I love history. England is one of the biggest treasure troves because we have so much history on these isles and things were so well-made in past times. &ldquoI will be a metal dectectorist for the rest of my life.

title: theme park blackgang chine uk oldest park
story: BIG THRILLS..... One of park&rsquos amazing animatronic dinosaurs (Image: Blackgang Chine)When Alexander Dabell cast a stone in 1843 to determine the reach of his lease on a windswept cliff in the Isle of Wight, Queen Victoria had been on the throne for just five years.&nbspGold would not be discovered in California for another five years and the world&rsquos first stamp &ndash the Penny Black &ndash had been in circulation for just three years.&nbspStretching about three quarters of a mile down to the shore from 500 feet above sea level, the land he wanted to buy was a wild and desolate gorge frequented by fishermen and riven with rumours of a thriving smuggling trade.&nbspBut Alexander, who saw himself as a pioneer in &ldquothis far flung barbarous climb, was determined to make his fortune by founding Britain&rsquos first amusement park there.                Thorpe Park power cut: Hundreds TRAPPED on rides in sweltering 35C                 Chessington World of Adventures CLOSED due to burst water pipeThis year Black-gang Chine, named after the coastal ravine where it is located on the island&rsquos wild southern shore, will celebrate its 175th birthday.&nbspIn the process it has become the blueprint for all the UK&rsquos theme parks. In some cases, quite literally.&nbsp&ldquoBlackgang opened before teabags had been invented and we quite often see ideas of ours popping up in other theme parks, says owner Alec Dabell, who is named after his great-great-grandfather.&nbsp&ldquoOne chap was saying how it is hard in our business to generate new ideas.&nbsp&ldquoBut I&rsquove got 25 years-worth of ideas already and I&rsquom growing exponentially. What I really need to invent is a machine to make more time.&nbspOne of his most recent ideas is a pond with a footpath through the middle enabling you to get a frog&rsquos-eye view of the lily pads.&nbspThere are also singing English dodos, a hall of mirrors, original rides, and the country&rsquos biggest animatronic T-Rex.&nbspBlackgang also has another illustrious claim to fame as the oldest continuously open amusement park in the world.&nbspBlackgang Chine visitors in 1922 (Image: Blackgang Chine)&ldquoDuring the war years the two slightly older ones, in occupied Denmark and Austria, closed but we remained open, he declares.&ldquoOf course we did! We were British and we didn&rsquot shut just because of a bit of adversity. As my grandmother used to say, &lsquoIf the Luftwaffe are overhead then you just lie still and pretend you&rsquore a cow pat&rsquo.&nbspThis is no idle boast.&nbspGerman planes during the Second World War frequently jettisoned unused bombs over the Isle of Wight following attacks on the nearby docks at Portsmouth and Southampton.&nbspAs a little boy Alec, who has an MBA and returned to the island five years ago after a career in the City, grew up in the ultimate playground.&nbsp&ldquoI had my own cowboy town and didn&rsquot everyone have dinosaurs in the bottom of their garden? How could anyone not have these things?&nbsp&ldquoFrom a little boy it&rsquos all I&rsquove ever known. My father is 94 and he put in the dinosaurs in the 1970s.&nbsp&ldquoI remember sitting on the sofa at home saying, &lsquoCan we have some dinosaurs?&rsquo and a year later along they came.&nbspOne of Alec&rsquos earliest memories is flying in a helicopter hired by BBC&rsquos Blue Peter who had come to witness the first batch of prehistoric creatures being craned in.&nbsp&ldquoI discovered that John Noakes smoked like a chimney but the real wonder was Mother Nature. Looking up at a dinosaur model and saying, &lsquoDaddy when you said it was big, you didn&rsquot say it was that big!&rsquo&ldquoAnd you can&rsquot argue with that.&nbspA few years ago Alec launched Restricted Area 5 and filled it with the largest animatronic dinosaurs in the UK, made to his specification in China.&nbspIn this way he continues to follow in the footsteps of his namesake who knew it would be possible to create gardens that would appeal to the romantic Victorians but sensed that he needed to offer something more.&ldquoWhen he started children were still seen and not heard, the Battle of Waterloo was barely over and tourism hadn&rsquot been invented.&ldquoIf I&rsquod been able to ask my great-great-grandfather how big the car park was he would have said, &lsquoWhat&rsquos a car?&rsquo Back then there wasn&rsquot such a thing as a business model but there was that really positive Victorian spirit that defied convention.&nbspShortly after Alexander bought his ravine a huge fin whale got stranded off The Needles, the most westerly point of the island and the showman saw his chance.&nbsp                Best theme parks in the UK revealed by TripAdvisor                 Rollercoaster HORROR as girl killed when &lsquopendulum ride&rsquo CRASHESHe bought it at auction, sold off the blubber, had the bones bleached and displayed the skeleton to the morbid curiosity of all who visited.&nbsp&ldquoBefore then you could read in a book how big a whale was but the chances were that you had never seen one or come across one, points out Alec.&nbspIt proved an instant hit and the park received the ultimate endorsement 10 years later when Queen Victoria herself came to view it.&nbsp&ldquoIn fact, she came four or five years in a row. Interestingly, 20 years or so later she offered a great deal of input into the building and the exhibits in the new Natural History Museum. As to where she got her ideas I couldn&rsquot possibly comment.&nbspBut he won&rsquot be drawn on current famous visitors.&nbsp&ldquoThere are various well known celebrities but we don&rsquot talk about them. We allow them to be the child within while they are here. That&rsquos the magic of Black-gang.&nbspAnd that alternative way of looking at things is Alec&rsquos raison d&rsquoetre.&nbspHe describes the thrill he gets from seeing the joy on visitors&rsquo faces and the pleasure returning customers gain from stepping back into their childhoods with their own grandchildren.&nbspOwner Alec Dabell said he has 25 years-worth of theme park ideas (Image: Blackgang Chine)&ldquoYou get to be that little girl or boy again and if you feel younger you are younger, insists Alec, who is reluctant to disclose his own age (57) &ndash it&rsquos the only moment during our interview when his energy dips.&nbsp&ldquoOh, age is such a grown-up thing and I&rsquom still playing and that&rsquos what I want to encourage other people to do, he explains.&nbspOne of the grown-up issues that this Peter Pan and his forebears have had to face is the erosion which has seen vast chunks of the amusement park lost to the sea over the years at nearly four metres per year.&nbsp&ldquoMy great-great-grandfather may not have been much of a structural engineer or have had any understanding of soil types but you wouldn&rsquot want to move it anywhere else.&nbspBeing here, I just can&rsquot help but smile. The sea breeze is nature&rsquos air conditioning.&nbspAnyway, we adapt and move inland and I reckon we&rsquove got enough land left for at least another 175 years, he insists.A few years ago Alec was at a conference of theme park directors and met one of Walt Disney&rsquos original &ldquoimagineers who recalled being at the opening of Disneyland in the 1950s.&ldquoI said, &lsquoExcuse me sir, but do you realise that by then we were already more than 100 years old?&rsquo&nbspThey would give their eye teeth to have what we take for granted. But if I&rsquove learned anything it&rsquos that we have to be a bit more grown-up about telling people we are here.&nbspFor more information visit blackgangchine

title: UK Weather forecast BBC Weather England Wales latest Met Office outlook update
story: The scorching heatwave that has engulfed the UK is to take a break over the coming week as a large cloud of rain is set to bring in heavy downpours across Britain and Wales, causing temperatures to drop 'below par.'BBC Weather forecaster Chris Fawkes warned showers will target the Kent and Hampshire coast in the early morning before moving inland towards London and the west mid-morning on Friday.The BBC Weather meteorologist said: We&rsquore looking at an unsettled day with rains or showers for many parts of the UK.Starting off across southern England, the Midlands and East Anglia a bit of morning sunshine but we already have showers across the coastline from Hampshire into Kent.                UK lightning map LIVE: London struck by lightning storm                UK weather forecast: THUNDERSTORMS and TUMBLING temperatures Mr Fawkes continued: Further into south-west England the showers are already widespread, not just on the coast but inland as well. Indeed, the showers as we go through the day will tend to develop further into a more general area of rain.That&rsquos going to be spreading in across south-east England into the Midlands and East Anglia as we head through the morning and into the afternoon. The rain is going to be heavy at times, arriving in London late-morning and the afternoon, looking really wet with some heavy downpours expected.Temperatures are expected to take a further hit after hitting the mid-30s earlier in the month: Temperatures 19C, a bit below par for this time of year. For Wales and also Northern counties of England, we&rsquove got widespread showers at the moment, some of these heavy and thundery. Got lots of heavy downpours.British gardens will get some much-needed sustenance over the coming weekend - the majority of the UK can expect to see persistent spells of rainfall, peppered with spots of sunshine.UK Weather forecast: BBC Weather warned heavy downpours will hit the UK at the weekend (Image: BBC Weather)The damp weather promises to bring the summer festivities to an abrupt halt as Britons are set to endure a wet and breezy couple of days.On Friday, Met Office meteorologist Alex Deakin advised, the wet and windy weather would be towards the south-east but would clear away overnight meaning that most of the nation would experience clear morning skies for Saturday.He said: &ldquoA sunny start, then, across Aberdeenshire and from Yorkshire down to the south-east of England.&ldquoBut we will see the showers in the west become more widespread.The Met Office also warned that cyclonic weather systems will sweep in from the Atlantic over the next week giving the weather a shake-up.Spokesman Richard Miles said: &ldquoIt is going to cool down across the country over the next few days while turning much more changeable.&ldquoThursday will bring a risk of thunderstorms in the north and west and on Friday, although there will be sunny spells, there will be further showers with some thunder and hail.&ldquoThese showers will be quite heavy, widespread and frequent moving in from the west before spreading eastwards across the country.UK Weather forecast: Map shows heat rocketing in two weeks (Image: WXCHARTS)&ldquoOn Saturday, although it will be mainly dry and sunny in the southeast, there will be rain spreading across the country with a risk of gales along the western coasts this is being driven by low-pressure coming in from the Atlantic.&ldquoFrom Sunday it is turning wetter, cooler and windier generally and this is the picture for the following week with further areas of low pressure coming into the country, we do not see an immediate return of the very hot weather.A shocking weather map however shows the heat is set to return, with thermometers set to reach the high-20s towards the end of August.According to the Met Office, the rest of August will be a mixed bag of weather, as there will be thunderstorms as well as sunny weather.The northern half of the UK should remain dry over the next few weeks but the south could be hit by showers and stormy conditions.Temperatures are also expected to be above normal - or even well above normal - at the start of September.

It later mutated in patients and caused encephalitis &mdash swelling in the brain &ndash which left iniduals in a fatal coma.After 20 months the virus, which was difficult to cure, had killed more than 150 million people in the simulation - and there is no sign of a vaccine being created.                Blood Moon eclipse prophecy: Will the world end TODAY - Apocalypse                 END OF THE WORLD: Natural disasters are signs &lsquoof the APOCALYPSE&rsquoIf efforts to create a vaccine continued to fail, Dr Eric Toner, a senior scholar at the Johns Hopkins Center for Global Health Security and the designer of the Clade X simulation, said 900million or nearly 10 percent of people on the planet could be killed.The simulation was as realistic as possible with a disease which could plausibly exist and included the technology and knowledge which we have today.Now, some Christian groups believe the study was a precursor to a real event, which has been highlighted in the Bible.The conspiracy theorists point to Bible passage Luke 21:11, which reads: &ldquoThere will be great earthquakes, and there will be famines and plagues in many lands, and there will be terrifying things and great miraculous signs from heaven.Website Sign Post of The Times states: &ldquoFrom the book of Revelation we read that war, famine and disease, (pandemics), will wipe out a quarter of the Earth's population during the first half of the Tribulation.&ldquoGiven the Earth's present population of 7.6 billion and that perhaps 600 million of those may be snatch away at the Rapture of the Church, that would suggest that somewhere around 1.75 billion people would perish, (with at least half of that number coming from pandemics if the article below is to be believed).&ldquoAside from the warnings of global pandemics, there is so many other things going on that indicate the shortness of the days until Christ's return.

title: EU news Craig Mackinley European Commission Italy Greece Poland Brexit latest
story: Conservative MP Craig Mackinlay warned the European Commission that its intransigence towards change and its plans for the future could push more member states to leave the bloc.Mr Mackinlay said several European Union member states have expressed concern over the direction of travel set in Brussels, insisting the bloc must listen to the demands of its members or see its structure changed over the next decade.Speaking exclusively to Express, the Tory MP said: The European Union is in real flux at the moment. I think Brexit is the least of their difficulties. The Commission is  of the treaties, it has almost become a quasi-religion for them, &lsquohow dare any country even want to leave?&rsquoThe EU has got some significant problems. You&rsquove got a parliamentary election next year on the backdrop of an increasing number of the countries that are concerned about the direction of travel.                Italian PM promises showdown in Brussels to tackle state's huge debtMr Mackinlay continued: There&rsquos certainly Italy, one of the big four, that has had a complete change of Government recently. Greece is obviously desperately unhappy with the situation it finds itself in.You&rsquove got the Visegrad countries of Poland, Slovakia, Hungary and the Czech Republic increasingly working as a bloc, with concerns over the direction of travel, particularly on immigration.With all that on the background, there&rsquos going to be a change of Commission, there&rsquos going to be a change of President, there&rsquos a lot of change in the EU.If it doesn&rsquot change quickly and reflect what people are saying, I think it&rsquos got real difficulties in the future. The EU you see today is going to be a very different one in 10 years time.EU news: Craig Mackinlay warned the EU Commission to change or face trouble (Image: EXPRESS.CO.UK&bull)The Tory MP suggested that Brexit could become the spark kickstarting a series of withdrawals if the UK is perceived as succeeding in its EU-free future.He also argued that member states could defy the common negotiating line set by the Commission to safeguard their interests.&nbspMr Mackinley added: If it is seen to be a successful history afterwards for that country that has left there could be others who want to join leaving the EU as well.I think things will change when we get down to discussing with the nation states because I don&rsquot think they are all that keen for the Commission to be speaking words for them that they really don&rsquot agree with.Mr Mackinlay concluded: In Germany, there are people who are working, there are MPs in Germany who need to get re-elected.If there is a tough Brexit that doesn&rsquot allow for frictionless trade, it&rsquoll be German workers who are put on the street and that will be the reality.We have an opportunity to change, the sooner as the negotiations get to the nation states the better because I think we&rsquoll be on a different framework entirely.Mr Mackinlay is not the first Tory MP to warn Mr Juncker of the risk ignoring member states&rsquo demands could pose to the EU.Nigel Evans said: &ldquo I understand that the European Union are scared that if it&rsquos a great success for the United Kingdom then other countries may wish to follow suit.If I were President Juncker I would look at the reason why it is that other countries are so unhappy with the European Union. I don&rsquot think Juncker gets the message.

title: brussels mad to knock brexit plan
story: We understand the frustration of those across the Continent who want to see a good deal struck — frustration at the PM’s failure to outline her position until nearly two years after the Referendum.And, whilst they aren’t the bureaucrats who sit round tables in Brussels — or have boozy lunches with Jean-Claude Juncker — there are plenty of business leaders and sensible politicians in European capitals who are desperate for Britain to sign a comprehensive trade pact.They understand that the future of the Continent’s economy is more important than the ideology of the true believers heading up the European Commission. The PM has — finally — started to talk to them with a concrete plan.The silence after her meeting with Emmanuel Macron is concerning, but the noises from German business leaders and politicians from the Continent in recent weeks are more promising.As the clock ticks, it’s time for them to tell Brussels that the theatrics and the anti-Britain briefings have to end. The Chequers fudge is not perfect. But Brussels would be mad to knock it back.And if they do? Planning is already stepping up for a clean-break Brexit.The PM still believes no deal is better than a bad deal and insists she’s ready to walk away.And that, as President Trump knows, is The Art Of The Deal…AND so another new front opens up in the war against the motorist.It’s outrageous that companies in some parts of the country could be charged if their employees drive to work.Those firms, who have already paid business rates for having a car park, will just pass on the extra cost to workers. Another stealth tax, another pocket emptied.We wouldn’t mind so much if we believed the money would be ploughed back into the roads, getting rid of potholes and fixing rocky road surfaces. Or if the trains turned up when they’re supposed to.But we won’t hold our breath.POLICE unions never fail to complain about overwork and stress on the job.We can understand why. It’s not an easy job. Coppers have our respect.But the news that one in 12 have second jobs suggests that not all of the wailing about long hours and working conditions are entirely legitimate.The next time a victim is told there’s nobody available to investigate, they might wonder what their local bobbies are up to.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: adrian chiles it is better to be a pessimist
story: I read this in The Sun yesterday morning and choked on my toast. I wasn’t surprised I choked on my toast because anything bad that happens to me — big or small — I’ve already lived through in my imagination.But I choked at the sheer obviousness of the scientists’ conclusions. Of course feeling stressed helps people deal with bad news. What next? Scientists discover sleep is related to tiredness?I can deal with bad news better because I’ve already been in that moment. I’m well prepared because I’ve actually lived it in my head.Anyway, the choking passed and, to my surprise, I didn’t die. That’s another beauty of always believing the worst will happen. What a wonderful surprise it is when the worst doesn’t happen.The toast didn’t kill me. I cheated the choke. Oh, the joy.I don’t know how long I’ve been this way. It’s definitely been going on since I was a kid.I remember flying off on holiday to what was then Yugoslavia with my mum and dad. I recall my mum trying to talk to me about all the exciting things we’d be doing when we got to my nan’s house on the Adriatic.I kept shaking my head and not saying anything and she got annoyed and rolled her eyes, thinking I just wasn’t looking forward to our holiday.But she misunderstood me. I didn’t want to think about the nice things we’d be doing because I was so convinced the plane was going to crash that it made me sad to consider what I surely wouldn’t experience.Imagine, then, my joy when the plane didn’t actually crash and I ended up not dying. What a bonus!And I went in the sea and didn’t drown — another nice surprise.I almost look forward to the moment when I do croak. If I have any warning I’ll tut and say to myself, “Oh well, I knew this would happen sooner or later.”This kind of attitude is admittedly a disaster when it comes to wooing women. Assuming total failure ahead of any move made on the opposite sex is disastrous. It’s just not attractive.I’ve a friend who simply cannot imagine why any woman in the world wouldn’t desire him.Consequently, many women do desire him. I, on the other hand, simply cannot imagine why any woman would desire me. Consequently, they invariably don’t. But because I knew they wouldn’t, I’m not remotely downhearted.I’ve kept the company of positive people over the years. They have their uses. But expecting me to believe them when they say, “Don’t worry, it’ll all be fine”, is fanciful.And believing that from professional advisers can be absolutely calamitous.“Oh yes, Adrian, it’s all going to be fine.” And then, whatever it is, turns out not to be fine and they just shrug and say, “Oh dear, didn’t see that coming, pay me some more fees and I’ll make sure it’ll be all right in the end.”In my work as a journalist I’ve talked to many psychologists who speak of the power of positive thinking. Yeah, whatever. Maybe. But what I do know for sure is that I just can’t do it.When you’re standing on a golf course with a club in your hand addressing the ball, you’re supposed to envisage your perfect shot. For me, impossible.What I actually envisage, with complete clarity, is a truly dreadful shot.I can actually hear the ball smacking on to trees, or plopping into water. I’m living in the calamity.So at least when it happens, which is often, I can shrug and say, “Hmm, thought so.”All this may stem from supporting a team like West Bromwich Albion. I once told a priest, in all seriousness, that I suffered from deep despondence.When he asked me why I thought this was, I told him (as a joke) who I supported. He nodded gravely and said, “Yes, I see, I see.”I have a friend I travel with on the supporters’ coaches to away matches. The poor chap always thinks we’re going to win. Even at 2-0 down at half-time he’ll be sure we’ll emerge victorious.I challenged him once about these absurd delusions and he said: “Look, we all have the same journey home after a game. If we’ve won we’re both happy, if we lose we’re both sad. The difference is that I’ve had a much more enjoyable journey there than you.”That convinced me for a while. So the next game I tried being positive.And we lost. And it hurt more. So I went back to how I was.There’s only one route to happiness I can think of and it’s to be found in the lyrics of a song by the late Mose Allison: “I don’t worry ’bout a thing, ’cos I know nothing’s going to be alright.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: self harming kids online trolls jane moore
story: She smoked (fags and pot), she drank alcohol (often in front of her liberal parents), always had what my mother would consider to be unsuitable boyfriends and was effortlessly academic, particularly at maths.Often, as we walked home from school chatting away, she would casually drag the back of her hand along a brick wall, causing the flesh to swell angrily and bleed.Other times she’d quietly press a lit cigarette into her palm, her expression never changing.“Why do you do that?” I’d ask.“It makes me feel better,” she’d say with a shrug.Sarah (not her real name) was, as I now know it, a self-harmer. But in those days — the late Seventies — it was rare and unrecognised.We lost touch a long time ago, but I thought of Sarah this week when I read that the number of teenage girls self-harming has doubled in the past 20 years.According to new NHS data, the number of hospital admissions for girls who have self-harmed has jumped from 7,327 in 1997 to 13,463 last year. For boys, the figures have stayed almost the same — from 2,236 then to 2,332 now.Worse, “self-poisoning” — as in taking an overdose — is rising for both genders and last month the Government released a green paper that said around 850,000 children and young people now have a diagnosable mental health condition.Experts say academic pressure is a contributory factor, so too social media.Kids have always had exams to cope with but in the old days jealous and bitter remarks were confined to the dark corners of secret conversations or, at worst, scrawled on a toilet wall.Now these brave warriors have a keyboard and pseudonym behind which they can troll you for everyone to see.By my age, you know the vitriol probably comes from a bitter, 53-year-old virgin who lives in his mother’s spare bedroom. But when you’re still finding your way in the world, that poisonous undermining can worm its way inside your head and chip away at the confidence that acts as an armour in life.One self-harmer told me the pain of cutting his skin provided a welcome distraction from the “washing machine” rotations of negative thoughts constantly disturbing his peace of mind.The majority of them can be helped if it is spotted early enough and the expert assistance they need is then easy to access. And therein lies the problem.In 2016, Theresa May said the mental health of children was to be one of her priorities as PM, but since then Brexit has taken over and little has changed.The Government’s strategy is to train more teachers to spot the signs, appoint 7,000 more specialists to child mental health units and cut the waiting time for non-critical cases to be seen.But even if it happens, it won’t be enough.Parents must also remain vigilant for any marked change in their child’s personality or behaviour and the big social media companies have the technology to stop the majority of trolls — so they should be forced to use it.If all of the above doesn’t happen, the NHS has another mental health time bomb coming which will cost the taxpayer a fortune and have an even greater cost to the mental well-being of the next generation.WHEN TV baker Paul Hollywood started dating a 23-year-old barmaid from his local pub, they were quick to point out that their relationship only started after his marriage to wife Alex ended.But Alex is reportedly not buying this explanation and is planning to name Summer Monteys-Fullam in her £10million divorce battle.Whatever the truth, it remains the case that many couples conveniently consider only full sexual intercourse as adultery.But of course, cosy chats, lingering touches and come-hither looks are all it takes for any man with a wandering eye to recognise that, should he wish to jump ship, there’s a shiny new model waiting in the wings to rev up his sex life.Hallelujah for the wonderfully pragmatic Emma Thompson who, when asked about her marriage to the dreamily handsome Greg Wise, replied that they have had plenty of rough times.The secret to a happy relationship, she says, is the realisation that there will be unhappy times and that, if you manage to amble through to the other side: “It’s always better.”She adds: “I think people in long, happy marriages tell a lot of fibs, like, ‘Yes, it’s been marvellous’, whereas I say, ‘Sometimes it has been awful’.”If a relationship is deeply unhappy for a sustained period then, of course, get the hell out.But in these Tinder times of endlessly sweeping left in search of the “perfect” mate (who doesn’t exist) it’s invaluable when someone high profile points out that, more often than not, sticking with the one you’ve got works out in the end.Altogether now, “Love is a decision, not just a feeling.”Daisy-May Demetres smile lights up a room.Just eight years old, she was born without her lower legs and now uses two prosthetic blades that allow her to live as full a life as possible.She attends mainstream school, loves PE and has just been given a modelling contract with high street brand River Island.Yet, because of her disability, her parents Alex and Claire admit to feeling a “profound sadness” the day she was born and asked themselves what they had done wrong. And when, as a toddler, Daisy-May had to endure a painful, eight-hour operation on her stumps, Alex admits he turned to alcohol and gambling in a bid to numb his feelings of hopelessness.But by the time she was four, Daisy-May had mastered her blades and was doing cartwheels and headstands.Alex, 35, from Birmingham, says: “I looked at her and thought, ‘If you can achieve so much, against all the odds, and still be cheerful, then I have no reason at all to be depressed’. I stopped gambling and drinking that day.”While no one would wish disability on their child, the Demetres’ story is a salutary lesson that, sometimes, what seems like insurmountable adversity through an adult’s eyes can, through a child’s simple acceptance and joie de vivre, enrich your life and give it deeper meaning.Following a cyber attack in Alaska, government officials have abandoned their computers and taken to using old-fashioned typewriters.Let joy be unconfined.I still have my original typewriter from my days as a junior reporter on the Solihull News and it was a loyal servant that never crashed, froze or ran out of battery. I may even request for it to be buried with me.It seems that my love for these machines is rivalled only by Tom Hanks (yes, that one) who has written a book of short stories about them and created an app called the Hanx Writer, which emulates the glorious click-clack sound as you type.Go on, try it. There’s no greater pleasure.No? Just me then...Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rod liddle building green spaces opinion
story: If it goes ahead with this, it will be the greatest act of vandalism against the British countryside in 200 years.It will also cost the Conservative Party hundreds of thousands of votes — perhaps millions.Because the people who live next to our beautiful open spaces tend to vote Tory.And they like looking at trees and fields rather than a Barratt estate.This is a crowded country and becoming ever more so. We’re losing more and more of our natural wildlife. Our open spaces diminish daily.And now the Government is being forced into building countless millions of homes. Why?We’re told we have a housing crisis. You might find this puzzling when you consider the birth rate in Britain has been dropping, not rising.The answer, of course, is immigration. We’ve been letting in half a million people every year for almost 15 years.The politicians try to tell you it’s nothing to do with our housing crisis — but they are lying. Lying to themselves and to you.One top academic expert, Oxford demographer David Coleman, reckons immigration is 85 per cent responsible for the rise in the UK’s population between 2000 and 2015.And the other figures you might find a bit chilling.Did you know, for example, that a whopping 28 per cent of all births in the UK are to foreign-born women? And the figure in London is a staggering 60 per cent.If you find an indigenous British person in London, say hello to him for me and wish him the best. He’s the last of a dying breed. White Brits are a minority in our capital.It’s not just that. The birth rate for British people is 1.75. The birth rate for immigrants is 2.06. That’s a very big difference.So not only do we let in half a million per year, but they have more kids and so doubly contribute to population growth and the need for new houses.Oh, and the need for lots of other very expensive stuff, such as schools, hospitals, welfare benefits and so on.We MUST call a halt to immigration. The overwhelming majority of the population thinks we need much tougher controls.And there are many people who think that immigration has not made the country any better, but actually made it worse.Cut the numbers coming in to 10,000 per year and our housing crisis would begin to lessen, given that 300,000 or so people emigrate every year.A net decrease in the population would massively reduce the need for new housing.Because unless we do that, the bulldozers will be moving in. The fields, hedges and woodland will be ripped up. The roads will be laid and the peace and quiet shattered.And this will not be a green and pleasant land for much longer.Katie Price has just managed to avoid being declared bankrupt.She’s been given three months to pay off a whole load of creditors, plus a whopping tax bill.Everyone seems shocked that she has apparently blown £45million.But that body needs a lot of upkeep. She spends thousands every month getting her nails done so they look really chavvy.And then there’s the periodic scaffolding required to keep those vast mammaries aloft – plus a bit of pointing and retiling.The surprise to me was how in the name of hell she managed to amass £45million, not how she managed to spend it.For doing WHAT exactly?A woman on a flight from Valencia to London apparently “bonded” with a “hot guy”.Now Jo Lia has launched a Facebook campaign to trace the poor bugger.She says he was called “Joe” and looked a bit like Jordan Henderson. Hmmm. But can he pass the ball sideways just as well? I bet she didn’t find that out. Anyway, above is a photo of Ms Lia.So Joe, mate – keep your head down and stay off social media for a while. If I had that loon sitting next to me on a plane I’d spend the entire flight in the khazi.Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn appeared on the Iranian-run Press TV to cast doubt on Israel’s right to exist.He used to get paid handsomely for his appearances on a network run by a hostile government which enslaves its own people.Meanwhile, more Labour anti-Semites have been crawling out of the woodwork.Here’s a suggestion. Clearly Labour has no intention of kicking out its Jew-haters.So I would suggest everyone in the party who ISN’T anti-Semitic get the hell out right now.And leave the party to the racist, hard-left rabble who are currently running it.The broadcaster Sandi Toksvig says that people mistake her for Tom Cruise.It’s easy to see why, isn’t it? Spitting image.Oddly enough, people often mistake me for the model Chloe Ayling.I even had the police round when she went missing because someone reckoned they’d seen her in Thornaby. But it was just me, nipping out for some fags.Our former Foreign Secretary is in trouble for having said that Muslim women wearing the full burka look like postboxes, or bank robbers.But that’s pretty much what most think, isn’t it?Boris was against banning the burka. But increasingly I think we should follow most of our European friends and outlaw the ridiculous garment in public places.Almost half of British 18 to 24 year olds don’t know when World War One took place, according to a survey.And hardly any of them could name the prime minister – David Lloyd George – who led us to victory.But it’s not really their fault, is it? Truth is, they’re not taught stuff like this any more.The history curriculum has been pretty much stripped of things which shows Britain in a good light, or British people being the victims of aggression.Instead, they learn very dubious arguments about slavery and colonialism.It’s a dangerous thing. When you lose a sense of pride in your nation, you also start to lose respect for its authority and its laws.And you raise a generation of perpetually whining airheads who understand nothing of the sacrifices made by Britons in the past.YOU see? They take their dieting really seriously up here in the North East. Pizza, chicken and chips. My missus took this pic, above, in a Teesside café.She once spent two weeks trying to find a salad in Austria, with no luck.The BBC is about to spend more than two million quid on a propaganda campaign to make you pay its licence fee.This is as opposed to the rest of its budget, which is spent on a propaganda campaign to convince you that all immigration is good, Israel is evil and Brexit a catastrophe.Fewer and fewer people watch the BBC.The licence fee has become an absurdity – an unjust tax which growing numbers of people simply refuse to pay.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: facebook digital wild west trolls sun says
story: These outlaws have long given up any responsibility for the digital Wild West they’ve created.Their platform is polluted from top to bottom, giving trolls free rein and letting every extremist group under the sun publish despicable propaganda.The previous Culture Secretary Matt Hancock was the first to genuinely talk tough to the tech firms and demand that they mend their ways.The new one, Jeremy Wright, must go further and force them to change, because they show precious little appetite to do it themselves.Yes, it’s vital that our privacy is protected. We’d never want authorities to have a free pass to snoop into our lives.But when cops are confident that the missing piece to a case can be found online, it is outrageous that web giants don’t work with them to investigate.They act as if they’re above the law.Let’s see about that.THE new Civil Society Strategy is better than its clunky name suggests.As a general rule, putting power in the hands of local people — rather than leaving it with far-off Whitehall civil servants — is usually a good idea.It is residents who know which roads need fixing, which bins need collecting, and which social care services are struggling.And for all the know-how of local councillors, too many are in safe seats and not solely motivated by serving their voters.Between plans for “citizen juries” and freeing up cash for community organisations, this should be a much-needed boost for local democracy — with the cash to back positive initiatives.The ironic thing is that it all sounds very familiar.It used to be called the Big Society.DAVID Jason reckons Del Boy would have been relaxed about Brexit.Of course he would. After all, South London’s finest never had much time for a racket — or at least, one he wasn’t running himself.And Trotters Independent Traders always understood that connections with far-flung markets were just as important as those next door — after all, it was New York, Paris, Peckham.It might even be an idea to send Del off to Brussels to negotiate.Let’s be honest: he wouldn’t cough up £39billion for a dodgy deal, would he?And if Emmanuel Macron asked for any more concessions? Au contraire, Monsieur President.When it comes to negotiations, he who dares, Rodders, he who dares…Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: chuck out chequers priti patel
story: How in the world did we get here? After the British people voted to leave the European Union we were told “Brexit means Brexit” and that critical “red lines” would guide our negotiations with the EU. So far, so good.Fast forward to today and we live in a different world. The so-called Chequers Agreement crosses all those red lines.We are dancing the hokey cokey with the Customs Union and Single Market, which means restricting our freedom for new free trade agreements.These, of course, are critical to the national economic success of Brexit. European regulations will remain in force — with no input from the UK. So we stay under the rule of European courts and provide a back door for continued freedom of movement for EU nationals into Britain.Our laws and courts will not be supreme as Chequers would leave us being run by remote control from Brussels.To frighten us into submission we are spoon-fed a daily diet of tales of food shortages, soldiers in the streets and tailbacks from Dover to Land’s End.But the political graveyards are full of people who underestimated the good sense of the British people, the very people who want to be in command of their own destiny and who don’t want to be taken advantage of by the EU.And don’t forget that despite Project Fear in the referendum, the majority still voted to Leave and the fear-mongering was proven false.So false that the fear of recession and job losses was met by a growing economy, UK manufacturing output growing at its fastest rate in a decade, exports to the US in 2016 exceeding £100billion — more than twice as much as exports to any other country — and the fact that our economy is worth more than £2trillion and is the sixth largest in the world.Project Fear was proven false and so will this latest version of fear, which speaks volumes about what the Government thinks of voters — sheep to frighten into the right pen. But sheep we are not.I’ve spent the past few weeks meeting party activists, businesses and the public, supporters of Leave and Remain from across the country and the view is that Chequers will give us neither our economic nor political freedom.Their concerns are simple. There can be no halfway house, where Britain continues to be out of Europe in name but is still run by Europe.There can be no halfway house when it comes to rule-taking and law-making from the EU, and there is an overwhelming sense of frustration that Britain is being taken advantage of by the EU.And across the heartlands of the UK this matters, as these people are the ones who have been left behind and who are desperate to take back control of our laws, our borders and our money. There will also be long-term consequences if the largest democratic vote in British history is frustrated.We will face a crisis of democracy in which ordinary people will utterly lose their faith and trust in politics and in politicians. The implications for political parties at the polls when they fail to deliver is clear, the public will stop voting for them. We cannot ignore the people.The Conservative Party could throw away hard-won gains in pro-Leave constituencies across the North East and Midlands if we continue to compromise on the referendum and concede ground to Brussels.Across Europe we have seen political parties and governments do exactly that and the result is a wave of terrifying extreme forms of nationalism and populism. That is not the British way because when our governments deliver, they deliver for our country and our people.The time has come for our political leaders to believe in Britain and in the British people. They should abandon the weak-kneed approach and instead play to our strengths. Britain wants to secure a trade deal with the EU and seeks to establish a “strong and special partnership” with them.Talk of no deal really means no trade deal, and if the EU fails to reach a free trade agreement with Britain, in the long term we can thrive under World Trade Organisation rules. The UK exports to 111 countries under WTO rules and over the past 23 years this grew at a rate which was three times faster than those exporting to the major EU nations.We also know that the European Commission, thanks to the many political problems across the European Union, desperately needs British taxpayers to foot the “exit payment” of £39billion to balance its budget.And 1.2million EU jobs depend on selling goods to Britain, with London providing much-needed financing to EU businesses. Brexit will not be easy.There is hard work to do but we are up to the task. We are a free and independent country and will prosper if given a proper chance.But to let the British lion roar again the first step is to chuck Chequers.The Prime Minister assures us freedom of movement will end and that we’ll be able to do trade deals. Others, including former Cabinet ministers such as Ms Patel, believe otherwise.It is time for the Prime Minister to sell the Chequers deal directly to the country.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: inside the ultra flash world of central asias rich kids whose dictator daddys and oligarch uncles fund obscene megamansions 1m supercars and private jets
story: Leggy heiresses pose in front of their jet black Rolls Royces, while young men dressed head-to-toe in expensive designer gear, lounge in utter luxury.The region may not always associated with luxury but bestselling book The Silk Roads tells of mind-boggling wealth from Central Asia.It includes an anecdote about the four-year-old nephew of a powerful oligarch whose financial adviser bought a £4.8million mansion in the tots name.Many of the privileged boys and girls featured on the Rich Kazakh Kids Instagram page look too young to drive, let alone afford the brash orange Lamborghinis and Ferraris they are standing next to.Dimash Adilet, 20, is a regular fixture on the page, though its unclear how he made his fortune.The handsome Kazakh with more than 700,000 followers describes himself as a role model with a membership to genius club Mensa.Whether hes pensively gazing over a white sand beach or posing next to a brand new six-figure Audi, many of his carefully choreographed images come with words of wisdom.One of him sitting on a Porsche reads: Nothing can stop the man with the right mental attitude from achieving his goal. Nothing on earth can help the man with the wrong attitude.Still - while they only dine in the best restaurants and holiday in the coolest destinations - how they can afford such incredible lifestyles is largely a mystery.Most of their accounts are private and they rarely go into what their families do to fund their globe-trotting, designer existences.But there have been young Central Asians who have openly flaunted their status and wealth on the world stage.They included glamorous billionaire Gulnara Karimova, the fashion designer daughter of late Uzbek dictator Islam Karamov, who disappeared from public view in 2014.She was often pictured next to A-listers including Jude Law and her designs featured at New York Fashion week until they ditched her over human rights abuses.Gulnara, always dressed in couture dresses and glimmering jewellery, also released a single and was known to have sung a duet with Latin heartthrob Julio Iglesias.Meanwhile, the son of former Kyrgyzstan president, is reported to live in a £3.5million mansion in Surrey while 31 per cent of his compatriots live below the poverty line.He was forced to flee the country in April 2010 after his father Kurmanbek Bakiyev was toppled following bloody nationwide riots.Maxim was so hated that protesters burned down his restaurant and luxury home in Bishkek the day after he left to seek asylum in the UK.

title: photos abandoned mansion wales
story: Crumbling walls, collapsed ceilings and dilapidated grounds, these grand houses, hospitals and halls are a shadow of what they once were. Many of these buildings are now overgrown, while some still have discarded scaffolding surrounding them.But all of these buildings are in urgent need of TLC.Here are some of Wales forgotten gems:The Mid Wales Hospital, originally the Brecon and Radnor Joint Counties Lunatic Asylum, was a psychiatric hospital in Talgarth, Wales.It opened in 1903 and was one of more than 100 lunatic asylums in Britain with the last ward shut in 1999.The hospital was also home to the Mid and West Wales College of Nursing and Midwifery and an alcohol and drug abuse clinic.There have been many failed plans to redevelop the site.Hafodunos Hall is a Gothic revival house near the village of Llangernyw in Wales.It was designed by Sir George Gilbert Scott and built between 1861 and 1866 for Henry Robertson Sandbach.The grand hall was subject to a devastating fire in 2004 and the ruins are being restored.It is a Grade I listed building, with many of the buildings and structures in the grounds having their own listings.Clawdd Manor in Newport was owned by the Lyne family until the death of Colonel Cecil Lyne in 1979.The Edwardian building was then a successful B&ampB before it started to fall apart.Baron Hill is in Beaumaris, Anglesey, and it fell into disrepair during World War I as the family couldnt afford to maintain the house.During the English Civil War, Richard Bulkeleys successor, Colonel Thomas Bulkeley, is said to have invited King Charles I to take possession of the house and set up his court there.Interestingly, parts of the park are sites of special scientific interest because the woodland has remained undisturbed for so long.It has a large range of lichen.This majestic castle in Abergele was built between 1819 and 1825 - and it has direct links to the British Royal Family.It was left to King George V by the Countess of Dundonald following her death in 1924.But local history claims that the first castle at Gwrych was built by the Normans in the 12th century.The castle was last open to the public in 1985 and has now been bought by the Gwrych Castle Preservation Trust, which plans to restore it and open it to the public. The spooky looking Piercefield House -  located at St Arvans, in the Monmouthshire countryside - was built in the late 1700s.It was designed by British architect John Soane, who is the same man behind the Bank of England building.Iscoed, at Ferryside in Carmarthenshire, is a ruined eighteenth century mansion, which was listed for auction earlier this year.The crumbling mansion was designed by architect Anthony Keck.It was built for Sir William Mansel in 1772 and purchased by the Napoleonic general Sir Thomas Picton in 1812 - it remained in the family until the end of World War One.It was then used as council housing, but has been empty since the 1950s.This grand castle was one of the first of the mock castles to be built in Wales.It was built in 1626 by Sir Thomas Morgan, Steward to the Earl of Pembroke.And King Charles I spent two nights at Ruperra Castle in 1645, shortly after the Battle of Naseby.In September 2010, Ashraf Barakat put the building up for sale - at a whopping price of £1.5million - and the castle was sold in July 2014.This derelict house is in Llanychaer in Pembrokeshire.Despite its dilapidated exterior, its roof is intact.Richard Fenton described the house as “a handsome modern mansion” in the 1811 Tour of Pembrokeshire book.The grand Cornist Hall is a large house west-southwest of the town of Flint.It was the birthplace in 1746 of Thomas Totty, an admiral who served under Lord Nelson, including on  HMS Invincible.Most recently, it was used as a dining and wedding venue - until it closed its doors in 2013.Unfortunately, the site is often vandalised.

title: muslim convert admits planning massacre 100 people on oxford street disney
story: Lewis Ludlow, 26, carried out reconnaissance on a number of possible targets, including Oxford Street and tourist hotspot Madame Tussauds.Ludlow, who pleaded guilty in court, even wrote down the places he was considering to attack before ripping the notes up and throwing them away.The sites he was considering included Madame Tussauds, Oxford Street - busiest time…, St Pauls cathedral and a Shia temple in Romford.In one note he chillingly wrote: Further locations scouted to kil. (sic)He continued: Wolf should either use a ram attack or use...on the truck to maximise death...it is a busy street it is ideal for an attack. It is expected nearly 100 could be killed in the attack.He hatched the plot in March and April after he was blocked from joining ISIS extremists in the Philippines.Ludlow, of Rochester, Kent, wanted to carry out a “multiple casualty vehicle-borne assault” in central London with the aim of killing more than 100 people.He had been due to stand trial but today admitted plotting an attack in the UK and funding ISIS abroad at the Old Bailey.A charge of attempting to join IS in the Philippines was left to lie on the file.He told police he was going to the Philippines as a sex tourist.The court heard Ludlow had sworn allegiance to ISIS as he prepared for the deadly massacre.He identified Oxford Street as an ideal target, writing: It is expected nearly 100 could be killed in the attack.Ludlow was arrested on April 18 by officers from Kents Counter Terrorism unit with his plans later found torn in pieces in a bin.Chilling notes included his plot to launch on Oxford Street using a van - noting the lack of safety barriers.Cops also seized a mobile containing photos taken on a trip to London in March while carrying out reconnaissance.They also found three videos where Ludlow - calling himself The Eagle spat hatred for unbelivers and ranted about his desire to establish Sharia law.He had established a Facebook page called Antique collections, for funding so that money could be transmitted elsewhere.The terror plotter transferred around £120 to a radicalised medic living in the Philippines.Prosecutor Mark Heywood said: The prosecutions case is that in February 2018, he tried to travel to Zamboanga in the Philippines.His intention was to join or lend support to Daesh or Islamic States organisation in that area.After that, his travel did not occur because it was prevented, so he engaged in preparing acts of terrorism in the UK.Ludlow will be sentenced on November 2. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: half of parents think swearing in front of kids is ok poll finds
story: Researchers found many will curse even if their children know what they mean.Two in ten modern mums and dads believe swearing is part of everyday language, with youngsters likely to hear it in the playground anyway. But they will only do it in front of them if their nippers know they are not allowed to repeat it.Two in ten also admitted they had been told off for cussing in front of a fellow parent’s child.Four in ten of the 2,000 polled have heard their kid swear, with “sh**”  most common.Many get round the problem with alternatives such as “what the frog”, “fire truck” and “bull spit”.Founder Siobhan Freegard, of ChannelMum, said: “Parents often use ‘swear swaps’ to keep little ears protected.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tattoos actually help you find a job
story: The University of Miami’s study proved job seekers have a better chance of being hired if they’ve been inked.It found perception has changed so much even a visible tattoo was not linked to individual employment, wages or earnings discrimination.Professor Michael French believes the markings are not only fashionable, with around 40 per cent of young adults having one, but show expression and creativity.He said: “In our sample, tattooed individuals were just as likely and in some instances even more likely to gain employment, and do not appear to have a disadvantage in the market.”Bosses who continue to discriminate against tattooed people may be settling for less qualified applicants, explained lead author Professor French.The latest findings show that tattoos in the workplace are here to stay.It is estimated one in five British adults has a tattoo.Two years ago a study of almost 200 managers in the UK and US also suggested having tattoos can actually increase employment chances where the clientele is younger.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: woman vandalises mercedes s63 amg baseball bat
story: The apparent drive-by attack happened just before 12.30pm today outside an apartment complex in Kent Town, Adelaide.Witnesses say the woman, aged in her 20s, was cool, calm and collected” during the rampage before fleeing the scene.The luxury Mercedes-Benz S63 AMG Coupe is understood to be a local businessman and it is believed the vehicle was only purchased last week.A bystander told Adelaide Now: “She turned up in a Mercedes G Wagon (and) she got out with a spray can.“She painted one side then went around and painted the other side, then got back in the car and got out the bat.“She took to the car with a bat, smashed up the mirrors on the side that says ‘cheater’.The eyewitness added: This is a reason why you probably park your car in a private car park and if you want the security of apartment living you should probably secure your car as well.“There might be some other business out of it as someone might be trying to offload an apartment now.”Later, a woman arrived and drove the car into the apartment complex car park — which is next to a crash repairer.She was approached by reporters, however, refused to comment.Police arrived at the apartment complex at about 3.50pm and took an incident report.They say the matter will be investigated.

title: family plagued 200 fly infestation hull dream home
story: They claim the plague has left them depressed - with more than 200 swarming around their kitchen EVERY morning.The unnamed mum and dad moved to Bilton, Hull, with their kids in the hope of a better life.But the plague has ruined their dream - and left them praying for winter.They said: We were happy to move to a big house with a big garden, but now we just dont want to be here anymore.It is just so horrible and is affecting us all mentally, as well as seeing it and coping with it physically, they said.The infestation is making me depressed and I just cant stand it going on any longer.Our children have diarrhea from the flies as they are always landing on the food - I darent even buy fresh food anymore for fear of the flies getting to it.This must be the only street that prays for winter - it was 52 degrees in the house the other day as we couldnt open any of the windows or doors for fear of more flies getting in.The unhappy couple are spending £50 a month on products to deal with the flies - which is costing them a fortune.They added: The problem is costing us a fortune and it is money that we cant afford and dont want to spend.We have tried everything to get rid of the flies and we are constantly hoovering, cleaning, wiping down the walls and mopping the floors where the flies have been killed.Hull City Council said: “We were contacted by the resident in July and we requested further information so that we could carry out an investigation into the cause of the problem.The resident supplied us with that information yesterday.We will be in touch with the resident with the results as soon as we get them. In terms of the cause of the problem, this cannot be determined until we have the results of the investigation.”

title: meghan markle hotel slave statues
story: The cast-iron figurines were put on display in the grounds of Cliveden House after being in storage for several decades.The mixed-race Duchess of Sussex spent the night there with African-American mum Doria Ragland, 61, the night before marrying Prince Harry in May.Blackamoor artworks, popular in the 18th and 19th centuries, usually appear in pairs and are often seen as depicting African slaves or servants.And the row comes after Princess Michael of Kent, 73, had to apologise for wearing a blackamoor brooch at a Buckingham Palace lunch also attended by Meghan, 37, in December.One visitor to five-star Cliveden House, a National Trust estate hotel near Maidenhead, Berks, said: “I think this is highly offensive.“Cliveden now has an association with Meghan as it’s where she stayed before getting married so it’s just as inappropriate as the Princess Michael episode.”And royal author Phil Dampier said: “They were unveiled just after the Princess Michael of Kent row.Cliveden were lucky enough to play such a lovely role in the wedding so the timing couldn’t be worse.It beggars belief.”The National Trust confirmed they were French sculptures made around the time of the blackamoor period and are in similar style.A trust spokesman said they were part of Cliveden House’s historic collection and were photographed in 1904 in its Duke’s Garden.They had been restored and put back on display at Cliveden House six months ago and had just been moved back to their historic garden location.He added: “Representing the diverse cultural history of the nation sheds light on past cultural attitudes and provides us with contemporary challenges, but it should not mean exercising censorship or shutting down debate.”GOT a story? RING The Sun on 0207 782 4104 or WHATSAPP on 07423720250 or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
